article.description: Jason Maxiell and Cincinnati used a balanced attack to win its ninth straight game.
article.headline: Maxwell scores 19 for Bearcats
article.linkText: Cincinnati creams Elon for ninth straight win
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- Jason Maxiell scored 19 points, and Cincinnati (No. 11 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP) used a balanced attack and an unrelenting press to beat Elon 102-63 on Tuesday night. Cincinnati improved to 9-0 for the first time in five years, allowing its defense and depth to make quick work of Elon (4-7). Six players scored in an 18-4 run midway through the first half that put Cincinnati up by 21. Elon got so flustered that it had three over-and-back violations and three shot clock violations, part of a 25-turnover game. Maxiell scored on dunks and pull-up jumpers, showcasing his versatility against an overmatched man-to-man defense. The power forward made all but two of his 11 shots. Field Williams added 15 points, and Eric Hicks, Tony Bobbitt and James White each had 13 for Cincinnati, which finished with its highest point total in 50 games. The Bearcats scored 33 points off turnovers. Scottie Rice scored 18 points for Elon, which lost two games in Cincinnati in four days. The Phoenix lost 75-58 at Xavier on Saturday, piling up 19 turnovers. Elon has lost all of its five road games, including a 97-55 drubbing at Wake Forest on Nov. 22. Even when Elon got through the press, it rushed its shots. Rice went 4-of-8 from behind the arc and had 15 points in the first half, but no one else could make a shot consistently. The Phoenix missed 10 of its first 13 shots, allowing Cincinnati to take control from the outset. Coach Bob Huggins complained about the Bearcats' poor passing and stagnant halfcourt offense in an 83-63 victory over Miami of Ohio on Saturday night. This time, things were much better. Cincinnati had 14 assists in the first half as it pulled ahead 55-29. Maxiell went 6-of-7 from the field, and the Bearcats shot 65.5 percent. Bobbitt put an exclamation point on the domination by stealing a pass with 5 seconds left and dribbling the length of the floor uncontested for a dunk. Huggins also has been unhappy with his team's tendency to go soft with a big lead. The Bearcats kept up the pressure in the second half, allowing Elon to get no closer than 24. With 10 minutes left, the Bearcats led by 35 and had five players in double figures. Cincinnati's defense also picked up, preventing Rice from scoring again until less than 4 minutes remained.
